content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Very good MMO Experience!Mabinogi has many features, the possibilities to what you can do are endless and the skills amount to that similar to runescape. Theres even a skill for egg gathering! You can honestly do anything on this game, tame a random mob, turn into a butterfly or raid the biggest dungeons.The combat is fun, with VERY cool looking animations, there is a wide variety of mobs for you to fight and gear isn't hard to get.It is not pay to win at all, the only thing you can pay for is Pon, which only makes your character look cool and occasionally it gives you that for free. Premium outfits are usually sold at the Dunbarton market for gold, and there are various, easy methods to get gold.Once you get bored of combat in general, you can devote your life to adventuring, or cooking, maybe even a grocery store clerk? This game can't really get too boring unless you hate life in general.The only downside to this game is that the movement gets glitchy once in a while and some of the animations seem to skip frames, either than that, very good play. (Also graphics are okay, but they are anime styled and wont be super good)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												Obvious flaws this game has include a very non-standard control scheme that takes a good bit of getting used to, a large amount of exploitable cash shop items, preiods of long grinding that occasionally become necessary, the worst customer support I think I have ever seen in my life, and a community filled to the brim with elitest♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥with little or no interest in helping new players adjust and progress at all and a pretty limited endgame. (if you can ever get there)Overall, however, dispite all its grevious shortcomings, Mabinogi is an amazing game. It has a massive pool of content and the options for character customization are as close to literally endless as I have ever seen in any game before short of going old school and playing D&D or some third party variant thereof. Something that I tend to use as a selling point is the games lack of a level cap. Basicly how it works is leveling up gets you ap, ap gets you skill ranks, skill ranks give you permanent stat boosts. Once per week you can rebirth, which resets your level to 1 but lets you keep all skills you ranked and all the stats they gave you. The game keeps track of your "total level", which is exactly what it sounds like, the total number of times your character has leveled up since creation. On average a powerful player can gain 100 levels or so each week between rebirthing withut any trouble, each level up grants you 1 ap, each skill on average takes 200-300 total ap to get to the maximum rank with extremes ranging from skills costing only 50 total to costing 500+ total. There are enough skills in the game that the total number of ap required to max out every skill is so high that my level 6500 main character is nowhere near achiving this, and I have participated in enough events that reward ap or double the ap gained on level up (events which are held pretty frequently) that my total amount of ap gathered is likely closer to 10,000. In addition to this they release more and more skills all the time. With this system the game rewards veteran players greatly as your characters power never stops growing. (this is even used as a theme throughout the games story) This means that with this game, unlike a game like WoW for example, the people who have put the most time into the game will be much more powerful then those who started only recently. In WoW particularly there is no diference in character power between a character that was created back at the games birth and a character that was created only a year or so ago. This does, however, lend itself to one of Mabinogis not so obvious flaws. With the way the level system is set up, considering the games age, it makes starting out seem like kind of a hopeless situation. Even my 6500 levels is relatively low for the age of the character because I have taken breaks due to events in my life or simple distraction by other games. This can be discouraging to players who, after their first few hours of gameplay, are most likely only level 30 or so if their not being assisted by stronger characters. This is, however, a problem that has in the past been addressed and adjusted for and likely will be again in the future. As of right now there is a feature in the game that gives new players whos total level is under 1000 items for easier transportation throughout the game world, items to assist in combat, free permanent ground and flying mounts, free premium service and the ability to rebirth every day rather then every week. This means that for your first 1000 levels, roughly 1/7th of what I accumulated over the course of 5 years, your progression is increased to 6 times regular speed (players over total level 1000 can rebirth only roughly once per week, every 6 days is the exact time) on top of being given other things to speed up the flow of the gameplay as a whole. This game also has a very involved and extensive crafting system and a huge range of options for gear customization and enhancement. In some cases, with good enough gear, a characters damage can be multiplied by 10. My critical hits average 12,000 damage, if I had fully upgraded and reforged gear (which takes an insane amount of time, in game gold, luck, or cash) I could potentially get criticsl hits of upwards of 100,000 damage. Currently I dont believe there is anything in the game that requires gear that good but getting gear of that quality is nearly impossible. (though I have seen it in action a few times before) Upcoming content for this game will be focusing a bit more on the endgame content, however, so we may one day in the very near future see content that does require the most carefully crafted gear possible.I would absolutely recommend that anyone with a computer capable of running this game relatively well give it an honest chance. Break that total level 1000 mark and play after that for a while and youl realy start to get into the meat of the game. Our community could use more new players who will stick around for the longhaul. If you want to play with me personally I play on the Ruairi server and my characters name is Blortad. Its worth mentioning that the 1300 hours I have logged on this game is only my play time over the last year or so since I started playing through steam. I have been playing this game for over 5 years, nearly since its relese in the United States, so bear with me if I go a bit too fast for you at first.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												I've only just started playing this game but thus far I really like it. A lot of the people playing are pretty friendly as long as you aren't rude and the game is pretty easy to figure out when you get in. The first thing I would want to say though is that going into this I did make 2 characters, one of them was used for learning to play the game, and the other was used to play once I figured the game out. idk if this was a good Idea but I feel like with the first character I was able to make all the mistakes I needed to make while learning and not worry about it affecting the rest of my gameplay experience.That being said it didn't take me long to figure the game out and if you're used to most basic MMO style gameplay then you should be able to figure out a lot of the concepts and UI placement pretty quickly. When I started I played as a basic human warrior and I have to say that I had a lot of fun with the combat. The fighting style with close combat is very fun and it feels like when you're hitting things you're actually doing something. The second talent I tried was magic because I thought it might be kinda fun to use magic at a distance and then beat my enemies down with my sword when they got close. I do have to say that to me personally I didn't think that the magic felt very rewarding to me. It seemed like I was just kinda poking things and making them angry and I found myself using my swords a lot more often.Another thing I noticed that I actually really liked is that you can go anywhere. If you want to wander into an area with mobs that are much stronger than you, the game won't tell you that you can't. I mean you will obviously get murdered going in there but I feel like it makes the game more fun when exploring because you don't know how powerful a mob is compared to you in a new area until you attack it. The sense of exploration and not knowing if you'll get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you the second you attack something makes the game a lot more fun for me personally.Again this is all low level beginner experiences of mine and the gameplay could become much better as you become higher level. I feel that this game is probably going to become kind of an addiction for me but this is also the first 2 weeks of me playing this game. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys MMO style games and loves exploration in games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Warning: This game, IMO is a WoW killer! Why? Well for many reasons, some more than others. Including:1. The rebirth system: This mechanic is actually the one main factor in all of this. Once you reach the age of 20 years old (Years in this game are weeks IRL), You can rebirth your character back to Level 1. I like this because it allows you to try different playstyles. If you're smart you'll actually invest in a playstyle that you like.2. The class system: This is a trip. See, the funny thing is, You actually don't need to restrict yourself to one playstyle. The only equipment restriction you have is in terms of clothing/armor. Classes instead give you access to learning certain skills that are exclusive to that class, as well as certain buffs. For example, The Mage class allows you to have an INT boost and extra Mana. This is also true for the Generational questline.3.Life Skills: These are unique in that they require a month of two of discipline to master! The variety is in this game. For once Devs kept their promise.Overall 8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Mabi is, in a word, unique. On various levels. This is a game where you will never have to worry about a level cap. This is a game you can play hard, or play casual and you will still enjoy it. There are probably bigger 'sandboxes' to play in, the thing about Mabi is that there is always something more you can do be doing. Typically the problem is there is too much you could actually be doing. Fun to play with friends, easy to run around solo. Like every game it has its bugs and glitches, and quirks, its jerks and amazing people all in a row. I do recommend it, however I also recommend do not give up on it on first impressions. For those coming from a more, traditional, background RPG wise, it can be a bit clunky and difficult to understand. Ask around in game, on the forums, check out the game's wiki (we all use it) and give it a few hours gameplay and a few successes before you throw in the towel and give up on the style and mechanics. If you like being a bit of everything, or wish you could play a game with complimenting skillsets (and play both or any skill set at the same time) you can here, and we welcome you to Erinn.

With tons of classes and quite a few people to talk to. Literally spent my first week playing just screwing around in town with people having a good time. Its a pretty relaxed game, or at least it was.Right now its mostly just people hanging out in town and showing off their cash shop items, chatting, and maybe dueling. Which is OK, but no one runs dungeons anymore, most just buy stuff from the cash shop. Its kind of hard to recommend playing since the community pretty much stopped doing any form of dungeons etc unless you get to the much higher levels of play where people are constantly doing dailys etc. Its also gotten quite a bit taken over by a lot of kids bregging about cash shop items and not doing anything else.Other then those few issues however, I have had more fun on this game than any other MMO I have ever played and Nexon fixed a few quality of life issues even though the game doesn't run all that great. One of which is their rebirth system in which you reset your level down to 1, but retain all your ability points (used to level up whatever you feel like training at the time: cooking, fishing, warrior, archer, cook, tailor, lots of things.) Rebirthing helps you level up and get the ability points fast again, and now free players can do this much more often. Once a week I believe which is usually pretty perfect.One of the best parts about the game however is that you can pretty much play however you want. I was exploring the desert for a few days, mastered some cooking, then killed some beasties in a few dungeons. Its pretty crazy what you can screw around with, and even though the community went a bit downhill, its still really good; especially compared to many other MMO's out there.If you are looking for a fairly relaxed game with tons of options and a pretty cool community, and don't mind the constant spam of people playing clannad/sword art music. Then download this and get to chatting and dungeon crawling. Its a lot of fun when you get some people to hang out with.Sorry if this review is a bit jumbled up, not a lot of time and its my first one. Best of luck in the world of Mabinogi!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Mabinogi is a severly under-rated mmorpg that is unlike any other online game I have ever experienced.  The player can reach thousands of levels high, partake in challenging PVE that actually requires strategic cunning and skill, and can make millions in gold through selling goods produced through one of dozens of the non-combat skills to learn.  In Mabinogi the player is not locked to a set of skills or class, (apart from a few racial abilities) instead they hold the full decision to progress in multiple different types of skillsets.  With the desired set of combat skills the player can then engage in combat that is not the typical spamming of the keys 1-10.  Technically in Mabinogi any player can defeat a group of enemies that are multiple times stronger than theirself as long as they have the skill.  ~There is much more to write but I am lazy :pIf you are looking for a unqiue mmo that stands out of the pack play this!

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Mabinogi is a long standing MMO by Nexon. The game features crafting classes and the ability to level any skill from any class for a fairly broad playstyle. The game is updated fairly often to this however it remains quite buggy nonetheless. Mabinogi is a free to play game with cute anime style graphics that appeals to teenage audiences, because of this the community can be quite unpleasant. My problem with mabinogi as a person who played it for two odd years is this:-The world is SMALL-There are very few dungeons with even fewer reason to ever do them-Too many shameless cash grabs by the cash shop.-Terrible community-Endgame content is nil-Buggy-Terrible eventsAs much as I dislike this game I must concede that after playing it for two years and for the most part enjoying myself it would be unfair not to recommend this game despite it's horrid flaws.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Among all of the MMOs and online multiplayer games I have played over the years, Mabinogi is truly a one of a kind game. Originally debuted in 2004 as a pay 2 play and transitioned to a free 2 play in closed beta, Mabinogi started off small with only a few towns and already had a ton of features that existed today. Though my only gripe as that even though it's a free to play game, you really get the benefits of the game by paying out of the wallet. Even though people say you don't need to. Over the years Mabinogi has tried to solve this problem by elimating some premium services and letting more free 2 play features into the mix.Now compared to 2004 there is always a lot of content. People who say who say it's "a generic MMO" haven't really looked deep into the game's mechanics and features. It's rare you find a game where you can use your own music in battle, or find a ton of minigames like you'd find in here.Still that doesn't mean that between 2004 and now this is now flawless. I still gripe about inventory space for free 2 play players. You most likely will be forced to get a pet eventually for lack of inventory space or buy their VIP service for more bags. Also their durability feature on equips is most frustrating, especially when it's not 100% chance that you might repair an equip completely. Some times even with a high-end computer lag might hit you as well, but that's unfortunately on the server end of the game. Also some quests can be a pain to do alone.But all of those gripes don't take away from the fun of the game. I highly reccomend playing the game through it's main and side quests for at least a couple weeks and join a guild and see if you are still enjoying the game.IGN: YuenRuairi server

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Nexon saw World of Warcraft, thought "we could probably do better," and then spat out an anime-styled cutesy MMO for the masses to enjoy. I've been around for a good portion of it's lifespan... and through every generation as things grew bigger and I became a smaller and smaller part of the world, I sat back and enjoyed myself more and more. The choices that are there now are expansive and there's so many ways you can build your character. Don't fret, because how you build them doesn't matter! REBIRTH allows for you to start over again at level 0 if you are tired of being range-based. So you can follow your Mabinogi dreams and become a chef or a great mage or even just a fun little bard. Speaking of bards, they have a custom COMPOSING system which allows for one to fashion a song of their choosing/making. The possibilities are endless, especially if you are one for running dungeons like a classic MMO player. One drawback I can see is many parts of the game are locked/hard to get to without paying a bit of cash. Some character customizations are also premium only too, but that's mostly vanity stuff. It doesn't make it pay to win necessarily, it just makes dealing with travel and some skilling much easier, especially with a limited source of inventory slots and hotbars for skills. I still find it worthwhile to pay a little so you can play the game at it's fullest potential. The game is so expansive that I can even recount a time where I was pillowfighting with my sister in Dunbarton as our mounts went nuts trying to devour us. From what I remember, there are Humans, Giants, and Elves for racial picks, but if you buy any pets they not only carry stuff for you/between your characters more fluidly, but they also can be directly playable, so buying a flying mount can make you a taxi as well.All of that I just typed... Only a small portion of what's in store if you're up for it. Seriously, if you are into WoW, it's definitely worth checking out. Just remember that just like WoW, it's best to play with friends... 'Cept here you can go a step further and marry your friends and make them your family. Then go family dungeoning and recount endless adventures across Iria with them around a warm campfire.Mabinogi has events all the time, so it's wise to check in on it once in a time so you get LOTS of free stuff and more to pick from.I give it a 8/10. In comparison, I give a game like WoW a 6/10 due to the lack of a deep and extensive story. Mabi goes, in my opinion, too far to fill the blanks on your experience. Plus with all the events going on, odds are you'll make friends that will explain it all for you. I've had many amazing memories playing this game, and I am SURE you will too!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												An MMO that falls just short of perfect, it has basically everything you would want in an MMO:-free form character creation that lets you constantly build your character's strength, forever-a wide array of awesome to goofy mounts-a pretty large open world-a complex crafting system that provides useful items-player homesteads where you can craft, farm, decorate, etc-a long and constantly added to story broken up into arcs that can actually be surprisingly well written-constant updates that add very significant features-frequent events that can be pretty fun-many different ways to play, and fun minigames to play, some for daily bonuses (ie - rafting, alone or with friends try to steer a raft down a river and used ranged abilities to kill goblins on the shores attacking you with magic and arrows, some melee ones will jump onto the raft and attack as well!)but there's some downsides that you should consider before you get into it:-pets and mounts cost money, although they do give you some basic ones for free now. limited edition ones can be powerful and extremely useful for certain kinds of crafting and playstyles so it's hard not having them sometimes-the combat is based on manipulating skills to counter the enemies and when you start it'll be hard to figure out what enemies are good to fight despite a "combat power" system that's supposed to help, it's not really accurate-it takes a loooong time to build up a decent amount of power, and if you start with magic good luck with that, some of the spells can literally take you years to get if you're trying to get them alone because you need extremely rare drops from hard dungeons-the game can be extremely confusing at first because almost nothing is explained well, they've started adding more in-depth tutorials but you'll still have a hard time figuring out what to do as a newbie-some people will be seriously turned off by the goofy cell shaded anime art style, but the screenshots are on the store page so you can see that for yourself. It can be seriously worth a laugh though when you see something like the pelican pet's running animationsin the end though the game's sheer volume of content that's surprisingly high quality overpowers the downsides so once you get into it the game's very good for being mostly free. I've played it since it came out in 2006 and I've probably spent $60 tops on it, and most of that was not needed to be competitive in gameplay.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												I've been playing this game since NA open beta. That's nearly 7 years! of course I've had some breaks in between, but no other game has drawn me in so much. Mabinogi is probably the least restrictive and most customizable RPG I've ever seen. You pretty much create your own class (Want to be a dual-wielding chef-alchemist? go for it.) and the lack of level cap means you can continously advance your character as much as you want. (Do not mistake total level for strength though!) Overall, after I stop playing this game years from now, I'll look back on Mabinogi as being one of my favorite and most memorable games.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Hardly find any MMOs that are worth some time and effort. This is one of those few. The fact that there are a large number of people playing this, some friendly, others that troll, as well as a unique skill upgrade system that doesn't cost any in game money (Save for a few), it's not a matter of what can you do next, it's a question of what WILL you do next. For all intents and purposes, this is what ESO should've been, and this was out years before any trailers for ESO... or Skyrim. However, the downside is to how dull things can seem to get, especially with repetitive gameplay. So, this gets a 4/5 for showing a unique side to MMOs, as well as having a multi-sided theme.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Mabinogi is a game where you need to be able to spend time, energy, and sadly for most gamers (ages 12-18 [generally): money. Otherwise, Mabinogi offers what is told by most game descriptions, age, unique combat, and plenty of costumes from any in-game event. Its certainly different from most MMORPG games, but if you want an easy anime life, then you'll need plenty of NX to spend. Either way, the dungeons have a decent difficulty curve, and the story is told in chapters, letting your character grow and develop on the way to the ending. The ending, however, is discovered after hundreds of quests you'll have to complete, and having friends to accompany you is very well recommended, and not just by the game. Some quests are near impossible without some comrades......and I speak from experience (damn golems.....). Mabinogi features plenty of skills to learn and master, and some of them aren't even combat related! Mabinogi is an MMO is one of those games you should play when you want to try something different, maybe even to play to meet some new friends. Either way, its your fantasy life!

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
												After 3000+ hours, I should be recommending Mabinogi to other players or those who are interested in it. However it may be, feel free if you want to spend time on the game because after all it's a one-of-the-kind MMO's and nothing really compared to it at the time. Though if you are wondering why I don't recommend it......it's because it's now lost many of the great qualities of what made this game most enjoyable.After all these years of playing, I can now say I wouldn't recommend it due to several changes.For veterans and newcomers alike, you'll understand that this game can be punishing, gameplay wise and economically wise. Learning how to play was a little difficult. When we got used to it, there was more to it and that was the fun part. Making those mistakes but learning from them and getting better and better. It's now spoonfed to you in the early levels when it comes to exploring and developing your character. Grinding is still the same as it is back then only the hard part is the later levels.When it gets too tough for, that's where microtransactions come in. They are literally the game changers including what you can get from exclusive events. That also means the economy has a massive overhaul due to the ease of obtaining the items.Over the past years I played it on and off. When I played it, I would literally spend so much time on this and when I took a break it would be about one or two months. I enjoyed playing music scores made by other players, jamming to those songs, questing with randoms and just chilling in Dunbarton with random players. The community was great. The keyword is "was".You still have great people and those who help out but now it's taken over by a lot of terrible players in terms of verbal abusers, scammers, hackers and griefers usually as a wolf in sheep's clothing. It's also come to the point where power balancing is ridiculous. One class that started out as mediocre becomes the strongest thing in the game and then gets screwed over again as the cycle repeats.Not only these issues aside, nowadays Nexon's recently gotten lacklustre with their customer support. I've noticed this in other games because for example 'Maplestory' they had banned a majority of players due to being exposed to a hacker and there was no way to get back your account at all. If you saw a hacker in Mabinogi or someone who was literally abusing the system and everyone else, they don't care. As long as they continue to get money for their ridiculously overpriced things then there's no support for you.In honesty, I enjoyed the game a lot and I do want to recommend it but it's become more difficult to and I don't plan on returning to Mabinogi with all my time spent there. It's bittersweet at best.If you do have the time (or/and money) to spend on this game and want to invest in this game because you are interested, I won't stop you. If you don't because of what I had mentioned or you simply don't have the time then I suggest looking elsewhere.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												I've been playing this game since NA open beta. That's nearly 7 years! of course I've had some breaks in between, but no other game has drawn me in so much. Mabinogi is probably the least restrictive and most customizable RPG I've ever seen. You pretty much create your own class (Want to be a dual-wielding chef-alchemist? go for it.) and the lack of level cap means you can continously advance your character as much as you want. (Do not mistake total level for strength though!) Overall, after I stop playing this game years from now, I'll look back on Mabinogi as being one of my favorite and most memorable games.

												Hardly find any MMOs that are worth some time and effort. This is one of those few. The fact that there are a large number of people playing this, some friendly, others that troll, as well as a unique skill upgrade system that doesn't cost any in game money (Save for a few), it's not a matter of what can you do next, it's a question of what WILL you do next. For all intents and purposes, this is what ESO should've been, and this was out years before any trailers for ESO... or Skyrim. However, the downside is to how dull things can seem to get, especially with repetitive gameplay. So, this gets a 4/5 for showing a unique side to MMOs, as well as having a multi-sided theme.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												First off, if you're into anime/manga-- great! Mabinogi will probably appeal to you with its chibi-esque appearance/graphics. The game has multiple facets (all not included here): you can dungeons, farm, do daily jobs from various NPCs in town, romance players with your music playing abilities. Your character can age, lose/gain weight... and you can even "reset" by choosing the "rebirth" option. Dungeons can be solo'd or done in groups: all set up in a labyrinth-esque scheme.All in all a good game, but it gets a bit repetitive/boring after a while. If you're looking to kill time, check it out: but other than that, Mabinogi doesn't have enough substance in my opinion. The added fact that there is a cash shop available for players that want to get ahead or customize their characters further doesn't help either.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												As a person who played this game for about 4 years since the beta and then on and off again to see updates, I can honestly say that this game is not as fun as it could be. It's got blatent cash grabs all over the place. One of the biggest draws of the game is the deep character customization, but most of the costumes available are from cash only events or directly from random box items in the cash shop. The gameplay is interesting but poorly balanced. Every update brings a new flavor of the month. Anyways, I don't want to be too wordy, so here's a pro/con.Pros:Lots of character customization in looks and abilitiesA fair amount of content in the form of dungeons and missionsInteresting battle mechanicsCons:Frequently updates are just cash shop updatesLots of customization is locked behind a cash wallPoor balance in PvP (and sometimes PvE)Often exploitable bugs that trash the economy (and Nexon doesn't do the best at cleaning them up)

												played this game for years, its a grind happy giant explorable world in a anime style setting and the effect of a fantasy life, wether you just want to sit back around a camp fire with friends, or cook, play as a bard and compose your own music, roam the lands, be a farmer, build a house, do quest, crawl dungeons, be a adventure, mage, warrior, pupeteer, archer, javelin, alchemist, merchant, fighter ( martial arts style combat ) , carpenter, cook, holy arts, medicine, smith, tailor, transmutation, trasformation master ( studying a monster enough to copy and transform into it ), and even more as new generation patchs continue to come, the game is easily worth a try regardless of what your into, if you give it a try add me- Icedelyne @ Mari Server ( Also there are now free weekly rebirths for every one regardless of total level )

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Mabi is, in a word, unique. On various levels. This is a game where you will never have to worry about a level cap. This is a game you can play hard, or play casual and you will still enjoy it. There are probably bigger 'sandboxes' to play in, the thing about Mabi is that there is always something more you can do be doing. Typically the problem is there is too much you could actually be doing. Fun to play with friends, easy to run around solo. Like every game it has its bugs and glitches, and quirks, its jerks and amazing people all in a row. I do recommend it, however I also recommend do not give up on it on first impressions. For those coming from a more, traditional, background RPG wise, it can be a bit clunky and difficult to understand. Ask around in game, on the forums, check out the game's wiki (we all use it) and give it a few hours gameplay and a few successes before you throw in the towel and give up on the style and mechanics. If you like being a bit of everything, or wish you could play a game with complimenting skillsets (and play both or any skill set at the same time) you can here, and we welcome you to Erinn.

												The only MMO that I've ever spent more than three hours in. Going into everything I think about this game would literally be super freaking long, so I'll make it simple. Technical wise, this game is crap. But everything else is great: A player community full of people who are usually very nice, MANY classes that you can choose, and a rediculous amount of quests. Completing all 19 of the main storylines is quite the feat, and even after having played this game for 400+ hours, I still haven't done so. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Very good MMO Experience!Mabinogi has many features, the possibilities to what you can do are endless and the skills amount to that similar to runescape. Theres even a skill for egg gathering! You can honestly do anything on this game, tame a random mob, turn into a butterfly or raid the biggest dungeons.The combat is fun, with VERY cool looking animations, there is a wide variety of mobs for you to fight and gear isn't hard to get.It is not pay to win at all, the only thing you can pay for is Pon, which only makes your character look cool and occasionally it gives you that for free. Premium outfits are usually sold at the Dunbarton market for gold, and there are various, easy methods to get gold.Once you get bored of combat in general, you can devote your life to adventuring, or cooking, maybe even a grocery store clerk? This game can't really get too boring unless you hate life in general.The only downside to this game is that the movement gets glitchy once in a while and some of the animations seem to skip frames, either than that, very good play. (Also graphics are okay, but they are anime styled and wont be super good)

												This game, in my biased opinion, is a great mmorpg. Truly a one-of-a-kind online game with unique lore, interesting characters, and so many wonderful things to do in this game! It's your fantasy life and you live it the way you want it; and let nobody tell you otherwise.People in this game are helpful, but you've got to reach out and take the initiative. My only gripe is the time limit on pets, but other than that, the system they have going on, and all the new updates show that this game is an aged wonder that still stands. I love this game, but I rarely have the time to play it anymore. If I did have all the time in the world, I would never leave the house again! Ha ha! If you're into fantasy and free choice to be whatever you want to, boy, this is the game for you! Just expect lag issues! Ha ha!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Mabinogi is a great game to casually get into. The lore in the storyline quests is great to follow (at least in my opinion). It, as well as other features such as flexibility in how you build your character as well as character rebirths make it unique and addictive. Since the game is old (made in 2003), you can expect it to run on just about any PC yet it has nice graphics for its age.The only negativity I see now is that since the game is old, many people might be turned off by its oudated engine/graphics and could perhaps use a refresh in these areas. I also fear for its decline as the developers may run out of ideas for the game's plot or that they could make a reckless attempt to add new content which may ruin a gamer's experience. On top of that, it is published and mostly run by Nexon, who has a bad reputation among some gamers, however I find that they still manage to fix most issues eventually.It's virtually impossible for it to be pay-to-win game since any paid perks won't really affect the character's growth , however a person who has played more will almost always have the advantage for obvious reasons. Most veteral players are friendly and would happily accept newcomers and keep the Mabinogi community alive, so if you're new don't hesitate to befriend some of them!Mabinogi is a free-to-play MMORPG that runs well on just about any modern computer while still looking good. It is certainly worth trying for any MMO fanatic and is more fun when working together with friends.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Definitely pay to win, but if you don't mind a little grind you can do basically everything without paying a dime. To a lot of people that means a lot, but not so much to me. What I find most appealing about this game is the classless system, you can make your character anything and at any point you can change your mind and pick up something else. You aren't limited to one type of weapon or skill set based on the race you play or the weapon and skill set you choose to start with. Over time they have improved the tutorials at the beginning of the game to make it easier for new players to get started and the community in this game always seems to have a friendly vibe. Overall, it's a great game and I would recommend it. If you're hesitant about it, it's free and trying it can't hurt. It runs on low spec systems fairly well and has a good look to it even though it's aging as an MMO. What you won't find here are cutting edge graphics and animations, but it makes up for it in gameplay. Not saying the animations or graphics are bad, they are very good considering the generation of MMOs this game comes from.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
												I feel like this game deserves a true review as it was such a major part of my life as a gamer a few years back. Though I haven't played it much as of late, I can honestly say that this was the best MMORPG that I have ever played. I was initially brought in due to the charming art style. As a child, I figured this would a simple, cute rpg that anyone could play with ease. While I was right about the easiness of getting into the game, the whole system as a whole is beyond amazing. The point and click system that was used early on was never cumbersome like other games I had played before then. Combat and movement felt fluid most of the time though there was the occasional moment of confusion on where my character was actually going.As for the story, I never really focused too much on the story as a child, I simply went through dungeons in order to level up. But after going back through some parts, I found the story rather charming. I was able to feel somewhat invested into the story despite feeling more like some mercenary that the REAL main characters used to do the dirty work. However, I didn't mind this too much as I still had ties to certain characters.Anyways, this is a game that one can easily get into; The community is mostly friendly, the controls work fine, and the general overworld is beautiful! My only major problem is that the economy seems to be in a horrible state ever since I played. Player shops rarely have items that anybody can afford. Though most items they sell aren't essential so it won't effect your experience much.My Overall Score: 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Among all of the MMOs and online multiplayer games I have played over the years, Mabinogi is truly a one of a kind game. Originally debuted in 2004 as a pay 2 play and transitioned to a free 2 play in closed beta, Mabinogi started off small with only a few towns and already had a ton of features that existed today. Though my only gripe as that even though it's a free to play game, you really get the benefits of the game by paying out of the wallet. Even though people say you don't need to. Over the years Mabinogi has tried to solve this problem by elimating some premium services and letting more free 2 play features into the mix.Now compared to 2004 there is always a lot of content. People who say who say it's "a generic MMO" haven't really looked deep into the game's mechanics and features. It's rare you find a game where you can use your own music in battle, or find a ton of minigames like you'd find in here.Still that doesn't mean that between 2004 and now this is now flawless. I still gripe about inventory space for free 2 play players. You most likely will be forced to get a pet eventually for lack of inventory space or buy their VIP service for more bags. Also their durability feature on equips is most frustrating, especially when it's not 100% chance that you might repair an equip completely. Some times even with a high-end computer lag might hit you as well, but that's unfortunately on the server end of the game. Also some quests can be a pain to do alone.But all of those gripes don't take away from the fun of the game. I highly reccomend playing the game through it's main and side quests for at least a couple weeks and join a guild and see if you are still enjoying the game.IGN: YuenRuairi server

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Warning: This game, IMO is a WoW killer! Why? Well for many reasons, some more than others. Including:1. The rebirth system: This mechanic is actually the one main factor in all of this. Once you reach the age of 20 years old (Years in this game are weeks IRL), You can rebirth your character back to Level 1. I like this because it allows you to try different playstyles. If you're smart you'll actually invest in a playstyle that you like.2. The class system: This is a trip. See, the funny thing is, You actually don't need to restrict yourself to one playstyle. The only equipment restriction you have is in terms of clothing/armor. Classes instead give you access to learning certain skills that are exclusive to that class, as well as certain buffs. For example, The Mage class allows you to have an INT boost and extra Mana. This is also true for the Generational questline.3.Life Skills: These are unique in that they require a month of two of discipline to master! The variety is in this game. For once Devs kept their promise.Overall 8.5/10

Also their durability feature on equips is most frustrating, especially when it's not 100% chance that you might repair an equip completely. Some times even with a high-end computer lag might hit you as well, but that's unfortunately on the server end of the game. Also some quests can be a pain to do alone.But all of those gripes don't take away from the fun of the game. I highly reccomend playing the game through it's main and side quests for at least a couple weeks and join a guild and see if you are still enjoying the game.IGN: YuenRuairi server

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Mabinogi is a different type of MMORPG that allows you to be good in multiple "Talents" (Talents are pretty much classes). The talent system allows you to be a Mage-Ninja-Chef that can dual wield guns; it really allows for you to be anything you want, and there are other aspects of the game that don't have their own talent like fashion (Tons of outfits). The social aspect of the game is what kept me on most of the time. It's just amazing meeting some overall nice people. The PvP in Mabinogi is broken at the moment in my opinion. PvP is 30% Skill, 20% total level, and 50% Equipment(PAY TO WIN). The current state of the game is laggy at times for my high-end computer, a decently low amount but just enough to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off bugs, and low in players on all servers except Alexina. I would totally recommend this game to people who are into MMORPGS and some that are just into RPGS since I've found myself going through quite a bit of MMORPGS before I played Eve Online for years and then came to Mabinogi. I've been spoiled by the amount of freedom that Mabinogi has that I couldn't even get into Black Desert. It does not make Mabinogi a better game than Black Desert but the freedom aspect is just very appealing to me. There is an Ingame market that allows players to trade almost all items for gold or exchange directly between players.----------------------------------------------------Pros+FreedomStoryCommunityCustomization----------------------------------------------------Middle Ground+-Anime style elementsPvEMarket----------------------------------------------------Cons-lagbugsPvP (Pay-to-Win)Graphics----------------------------------------------------If you join Mabinogi feel free to send me a note (IGN: Kavah | Server: Alexina)

												EDIT 2: This game is quite interesting to the fact that you can learn other skills and talents by using the item associated with the action/talent. For example:I use a bow "You have gained knowledge about the Archery Skill!" I read a book on magic,"You have gained knowledge about the Lightning Bolt Skill"! I don't have too terribly much expierience with MMORPGs,but I still think this feature is great. Being able to become a Martial Arts Mage,or an Alchemist Archer,or an Chef Knight. and so forth.EDIT 1: The video on the store page is what the players of this game dream of.The game is still great,but there's just not a lot of player-to-player interaction anymore. If you want action in this game,you'll have to make it yourself. The servers aren't very crowded (hooray?).Sadly,almost everyone online is away-from-keyboard,BUT there are a few good souls who will be your friend and help you out.ORIGINAL:It's a good game,as far as I've played. It's controls will take some getting used to(space bar,for example,isn't a 'jump' button,but it's the combat mode on/off button).It's a manga/anime massivley-online multi-player role playing game. The Inventory isn't THAT big,not a problem for me,maybe for someone else,but not me. And MAN,you can choose you AGE when you are creating your character,so here's a game where you can kick rear as a six-year-old(I may be wrong). Gold isn't too hard to find,but you'd better be loaded when you go shopping!If you want to know the Plusses of the game,play for yourself,or read someone else's review,BUT PLEASE,NEXON,ADD BACK INTO THE GAME THE PARTNER SLOT!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Having not even 10 hours into ann MMO game, so my point of view is only really of the first impressions I got of the game.  10 hours is still a hefty amount of time spent on one thing, though, and do I have a wall of text of an opinion on it.VISUAL:  Nothing noteworthy graphics-wise, if not even decent.  It’s a shame you can’t see more of what’s happening since the draw distance is abysmal, even with highest settings.  The camera will go out of control in certain areas (such as Bangor with their tight cliff walls), and one of my first game experiences had me stuck in the first quest giver’s building as the camera glitched out and could not zoom or focus enough to see the exit door and leave.The minimap is only useful for seeing where you are, as by default it shows no other players and party members are represented by delayed or outright wrong last seen locations.  The HUD is your standard MMO fare, but beware when you increase the resolution; it shows its age and the thing becomes so small it is near unreadable.SOUND:  Really not much to say here, it will probably be too loud by default when you first start it up.GAMEPLAY:  Skill system seems like a good idea on paper, being able to strengthen which skills you want by using them more often and in certain ways, but quickly shows its flaws.  “Windmill” move in particular, unless you use this move exclusively early game I don’t know how one can max this skill out.  I got to the point where it will only gain experience if I use it on “powerful” enemies, but even using it on enemies classified so soon became impossible; progression on the move completely stalled simply because I leveled up too much before the exponential growth of the enemies overtook me.  Even using it on a dungeon boss did not qualify as being “powerful” despite being able to destroy our entire group with one swing.  Which brings me to the next issue, the rampant spikes in enemy strength.  The particular dungeon was filled with goblins and imps that we could all easily defeat without a scratch on us, if they even get a chance to hit us before we systematically genocide the entire ruin.   Then comes out the bosses (plural), each one we can barely put a dent in before severely or outright killing a member of the party.  Practically no prior warning to the sudden player abuse that was waiting for us.  Similar experiences from friends who were grinding in the underpowered monster areas that for some odd reason had something incredibly more powerful mixed in.The combat system does not help fight them either.  While, once again, the pseudo RPS and timing oriented turn based combat sounds at least a step above an average click-based combat, connection issues plagued half the battles I was involved in.  Animations skipped and enemies warped, my computer and internet was more than enough to handle this game, yet I easily kept getting stunlocked due to me sometimes not being able to make a move from the input lag (unless this is normal, then which case being stunlocked by PvE is ♥♥♥♥ing annoying).When not in combat, the inventory is a mess.  Items had no pattern that I could see whether it could be stacked or not, a single sheet of paper can take up the same amount of space as a pair of shoes, if items can be stacked most of the times they cannot be stacked high, if you were to accidentally use a stack of items for a cooking ingredient the entire stack was used instead of the single item, etc. etc.  The worst was how much space gold takes up the inventory, especially considering how ridiculously expensive everything is, even more so considering how as a beginner player most of it was practically inaccessible.TL;DR:  Everything feels clunky, and a common thought while playing the game was: “This could be done better.” 3/10

												I personally enjoy Mabinogi, It's got the same MMORPG Stuffs, But its very unique in its combat. You have your basics; Attack, Defense, CounterAttack, and Windmill. Windmill is the unique part, Its like a AoE Melee Leg Sweep Attack, And of course you have your class skills and weapons! Theres honestly so much to do in this game! The only downsides are; Because of this games unique playstyle, some may dislike it right away. I also got bored after a long time of playing, (About 9 months I'd say) But after awhile, I always see myself coming right back in to start the process all over again. Overall I recommend this game to any people seeking a new MMORPG Anime Game. And if you even read this far into this, if you are intrested in this game or not, I'd do insist you download and try it out for yourself. First-Hand Experience is the only way to really get how this game works. Have a nice day!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Personal review 9.5/10Objective review 5/10I love this game. I played this game since it was beta and this is game that literally grew up with me. Whenever I play this game I have nostalgic feeling of me playing this game when I was elemantary student. Some people say WoW is game that people can never quit, but keeps on coming back, but for me this is a game that I will never ever quit (unless it closed down) and will probably be my first and last MMORPG.Reason I like this game so much is you have so much things to do. You can play this game socially by joining guilds. You can play this game going through quests. You can play this game playing music within game with different kinds of instruments. You can play this game doing all kinds of things such as trading/farming and so on. Even though graphic may somewhat look outdated, it kinda shows how old this game is.However, I also find it disturbing how this game changed so much to pay to win. While this game is free to play and therefore you dont have to pay any money, in reality, you kinda do if you want to take some part in the game. For beginners this game can be really hard because if you start this game literally from the blank, you will have tough time going through anything. Even though there are many features u can enjoy, you need funds. So overall do I recommend this game? Yes I do. Even though this game has gotten somewhat pay to win game, regardless it is great game and there are so many things you can to enjoy this game. If you are tired of WoW type MMO which just repeats quest - raid - pvp cycle, I definitely recommend this game. I wish future MMO adapts Mabinogi.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												Mabinoji is overall a well polished game. The graphics and theme are appealing and I found this game very fun to play. However, I have always had a problem with it's quests. Sometimes, they tell you to return a quest to an NPC, and they don't tell you where the heck that NPC is. I am sometimes really frustrated by this. Also, this is not a game that you can play solo. The dungeon's difficulty increases exponentially. The first maybe two dungeons you could do on your own, but anything after is nearly impossible without a party. Also the inventory idea in this game is terrible. You have like 100 inventory space in your bag. Tht doesn't sound too bad right? Think again. The Items aren't limited to one inventory space, so I often have to throw things away just to get my reward for my quest. This feature does make the game more realistic, but it makes the game feel less and less fun. The storyline is pretty good, but it is hard to follow, because you have to complete a dungeon to get to the next storypoint. And as I mentioned earlier, you just can't solo it. This game does have many problems, but I would definitely recommend playing it.

It was just so cool to do trade runs, gather materials for crafting, attempt and often fail dungeons because I suck at combat... if I recall correctly the last thing I was doing was collecting creatures so that I could transform into them.I met a lot of interesting folks. One player posed as a dog and just barked and followed me around for a day. He helped a friend and I complete a tough dungeon and generally made that day's experience a ton of fun.The game is a bit antiquated in some respects but I was easily able to look past that and have a good time.Give it a fair try, maybe with a couple of friends, or make a couple of new ones in there. Or go solo if that's what you really want to do, maybe take pictures and do a blog about your journey.Just settle on down and play yourself some Mabinogi, bro. Enjoy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Playing Mabinogi is one thing I'll never regret. The memories I've made playing with friends I made will probably be some of the most long lasting. Honestly the community made the game for me. Playing Mabinogi solo will definetly start to get boring after a while, as most of the solo content is a grind fest other than the Saga. So I would definetly recommend trying to reach out and make friends to play with. Other than the community, the game was alright. The fighting style is unique and different than most MMOs out there. Plus there's a lot of space to move around in as they give you opportunities to "Rebirth" which allows you to change your class or proffession and restart yourself to lvl 1 while keeping all of your previous stats. But I would highly recommend sticking with a combat class to start with in the beginning as it's always nice to have a a certain class that you can lean on. Another thing that I liked about this game is that the devs keep a constant amount of events to do every now and then to help keep you entertained. They also interact with their player base occasionally getting on, or through events where you can spend time with them. And if you ever so wish, you could also stalk them on twitter if that's your thing. But the devs in Mabinogi are probably the most interactive I've ever seen in an MMO. They also have interactive NPCs which I find pretty interesting. All in all my experiance with Mabinogi was mostly postive. Reading some of the reviews from old time players, seeing them leave is honestly a bit sad as it's thanks to them that we newer players are able to experience the best out of this game as some of them spent their time putting a whole bunch of info on a Wiki for us, so if you decide to play I'd definetly recommend you check it out. Mabinogi might not ever be as it once was for them, as their expectations may have been shot down, but for new casual players, I don't think it should be much of a problem.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Well, where to begin? This game has aged poorly in the aspect that it doesn't run too well on modern systems. Otherwise for being 8 years old it has a fairly active (and friendly) community. To this day it still sees updates and varying other things. This was one of my first MMORPGs (the other being Fiesta). Seeing it grow and change has amazed that something can run for so long. I wish they would've released Mabinogi 2 (not that Vindictus♥♥♥♥♥♥ so Mabi could continue to run for another generation of gamers. But onto the actual review and not nostalgia. This game is a very unique MMORPG being advertised as "you can be anything!" And it doesn't lie. You can be a singer, a battlemage,  a archer, or a combination of the varying amounts of skills in this game. The levelling system is unique as in you can level and then "rebirth" your character which results in removing your current levels but you keep your skills. Your levels are, in a sense, saved in a total level. Mine being about 500-700, is fairly low, especially seeing as I have friends who have multiple characters at 4K+ levels. One of the downfalls is the sort of need of pets because you'll eventually run out of space. Going onto another downfall is how poorly it runs on current systems. This game was made 8 years ago and it struggles to support current-end parts. The community, when they aren't AFKing in Dunbarton or wherever, are usually super friendly and are willing to guide you through almost anything. One thing I do miss is some of the people I used to play with when I was a lot younger but dropped Mabi due to IRL things and lost contact with. But even then, I've found new friends who in a sense replace them but are completely unique from my original friends. All in all, if you disregard the graphics, this is an amazing game that truly needs a reboot on a new engine.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I'm going to re-write my review of this game, just because it has changed since I played it. Unfortinitly, my thumb is still going to point twords the floor.  This game has a good sized world, it has many skills, and over the years has had some very nice improvments and new content. It also still has many bugs and while new stuff does get added and older programming does get changed at times, older textures and meshes rarely ever get updated, specialy if they involve wearables.   I wont go over skills and such much, I recommend trying the game for yourselves for that, but I will warn you that this game is not great at being pay-free as some would like to say, as pets ($), while unneeded, are about as unneeded as a car is, it's not a great idea to advoid them. There are boosters and the such you can buy with money aswell, but most of these actualy are not needed unless you're looking for a edge, but pvp is kinda a dead joke in this game. Then you get Nexon's -Amazing- customer support, of which I can only assume work at EA as well. Really, you -will- get problems with them eventualy, eithor through payment info randomly being perma blocked or through them randomly banning accounts. I have not had my account banned, but I have had friends, ones that don't do stupid stuff, get banned for no reason and dispite many ticket requests never get a reason as to why or a way to defend themselves.   Another downfall of this game is the extream lack of keybinding. while you can shortcut some UI keys, anything skill-related you are stuck with # keys and F# keys. No exception unless you own a Naga, in which case... why are you looking at this game?! (To be fair, I do not own a Naga mouse, and am just assuming the hotkey-program that it uses will works with mabi)    Now, I have a lot of gripes with this game and its p*ss poor support, but I also have a lot of great memories with it. As the saying goes, it's not the game that makes it fun, it's the people, and there is a good amount of good people in this game. As a new player, you also get a good amount of story quests and exploration to do, which I highly recommend exploring the world before trying to save it.   It is not a bad game, more that it is ran by a bad company, which as much as it dissapoints me, is the main reason why I can not give this game a good review, because it is loosing players every year, and Nexon just keeps trying to milk it for money, providing new content as a way to try and draw new players in to their failing game. Unfortinitly, their business practices will not change, and that will keep most new players from staying.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I used to hate this game's guts. I don't know what it was (this was a few years back) - the cutesy character designs, the clunky combat, or the complete lack of a discernable main quest. However, I've recently given it another try - and damn is it a good game.Mabinogi is a sandbox MMORPG published (unfortunately) by the (in)famous Nexon - so of course, it's a KMMO. Don't let that turn you away if you're afraid of the grind usually associated with games like MapleStory and Ragnarok though! The game has rather unique mechanics that keep the game from ever really feeling like a slog. The game came out in 2003 (and it hardly looks it), and has been consistently updated with more content.The game is heavily focused around 'life skills' - generally non-combat skills, such as fishing, tailoring, and even songwriting. That's not to say that you can't crawl through dungeons and slay beasties, however. It merely gives you the opportunity to take a break, play the lute (unfortunately, there's no Lute Hero minigame), mine some ores, or make some clothes. You can even build up a base in what's oddly similar to a Farmville clone in a separate instance from the main world. As you craft, kill, and gather, you'll earn experience both towards your character level and your skill levels. As you increase your skills and advance them with the use of Ability Points (earned from level-ups and quests), you'll also gain permanent stat increases for your character, from HP to Intelligence. These permanent stat gains seem minor at first, but as you start branching out your skills (you go from ranks E to A, then 1 to 9 in each skill), your character will become much more formidable, and you'll unlock stat-altering titles to boot.The most unique thing about the game is the Rebirth system. After your character's been around for a week real time, you can have them be "reborn" and reset to level 1 (and change their appearance if you so desire). The benefit to this is mostly farming AP, but your skills and permanent stat ups remain. Leveling up, for this reason, doesn't take an obscene amount of time.Questing in the game is, unfortunately, rather generic. You'll randomly gain "Hunt" quests (kill quests), but you can also talk to NPCs to start quests that have at least some minor amount of plot to them (though they still amount to fetch/kill quests). The flavor text does add life to the game world, as there's usually some reason you're being told to slaughter wolves or crawl through the local hive of spiders. Along with this are the Story quests and the Event quests. Events are usually to mark a large release, such as character animal transformations, or a holiday. Story quests vary from a Mabinogified version of Shakespear's Hamlet (no joke; it's amazing experience, too) to the typical "the goddess sent you to x" RPG fare. Still, I can't help but smile at the quest complete jingle.Speaking of music, holy Christ in Heaven, this game has a top tier soundtrack. Whether you're adventuring on the open plain, relaxing in town, or slaying beasts in the caverns below, the music is bound to have you grinning or humming along. My personal favorite tune is in Tir Chonal [or however you spell it], the human starting town.Unfortunately, as far as I can tell in my 15 hours of play (I have more off of Steam), there doesn't seem to be any real endgame beyond the Advanced and Expert dungeon crawls. If someone could correct me on that, I'll put a note in the end of the review.Overall, I have to recommend you at least try the game if you don't absolutely despise anime (which this game is drenched in the cologne of). It's a fun game, and you have nothing to lose but temporary computer space.

												 This game has no finish but that's what I like about it, at least every month or recently the game hosts awesome events for players to play. As you continue to play the game you understand you don't need to finish all the quests in a certain time limit. You can play around with other players, go rafting, hot air ballooning, hunt, collect transformations, do generations, run dungeons, get achivements, sell items, create items, make food, work on skills, look fashionable, window shop, duel, run shadow missions, collect food items such as( berries, apples, mushrooms, etc.), gather a ton of gold, own tons of outfits, explore iria's secrets, hunt down black dragon/white dragon, visit hillwen mine, collect ores, create dyes, work on homestead, make crops, achieve friendship, become friends with npcs, focus on events, win rewards, join fashion show, play music, create music, sing, dance, find weird glitches, play around with gestures, get married, play the saga I/ saga II, and lotssss more. I rlly reccomend this game for people looking for adventure, and all the stuff I listed above.

												Hi it's Mininight From Alexina Server Here.This is My personal Review on Mabinogi.First things first, I Am An Old, Player, Not the kind that afk, leave game open. I can usually be on most days of the week, But enough about me, this is about the game.This game Used to really give you the sense of Adventure, and exploring the continents, without so many moon gates and the moon gate book, It used to let everyone explore, you used to be able to be with friendly groups of people to hangout with  and do things in the game with, that aren't trolls, scammers. and worse Them Alts... etc. But now it's kinda full of them. You also used to get the feeling of achieving something good. That is gone now to.I don't like how every begginer player gets recomended to do ninja talent. That is unbelievably grindy, and ive done it. Will make you want to quit, For awhile. or forever. But i do like the reset feature benefit, But i think it needs to be explained more, To new players, So you can learn how to exactly train each skill and talent. Also Explain how to get ap from it, its a very useful feature, alot of people ignore, and don't know of it. This Game has so much Potential. But i don't like how its all going down the drain.The Market is really crazy, also can be very hard. If it's crafting or selling mats, all im going to say is that its super grindy and when you sell the stuff and or gear, People are willingly to buy it in bulk and under valued... So your kinda better off crafting for yourself or for your friends..Life skills are very Grindy and need to be updated badly. Same with obtaining some materials easier like fine finest leathers. Increasing the fishing list and have a fishing contest mini game. some other stuff to.The guild system has been alright, But that need to be updated to, especially the guild features Like The guild hall, should atleast be able to decorate it. Also the Guild robe. The Guild pvp has potential. At the moment not that good.pvp about pvp, It needs to be balanced properly, Also the pvp currently is kinda bad because its full of stunlocking, to me that's super cheap and boring...Commercing, I used to like commercing but i tend to get a dismounting/ mounting problem. Commercing can be fun and worth it, if the commerce shop gets updated, Bounty hunting can be fun. Rafting i used to enjoy rafting, But that honestly needs to be updated and it's really displacement buggy. Same with the rafting shop id like to see some better stuff in there. The current way of the Spirit Weapon System is Built it, ehh, Really not worth it, can take years to get the gems and powders and so much money to level one up Also maintain it's dura. Also Needs to Be updated. Like adding the rest of the weapons to the list. Repair rate I honestly think it should stay and be at 100% without having your item, losing max dura, because it'd cost so much to get the dura back up. That and upgrading enchanting and reforging an item is so costly, Nobody really deserves it being not useable. Because of dura.Shadow missions can be fun, But the end chests need new and better stuff. Would like to see new bosses, etc in them. Also new shadow missions. As for shadow crystals, People way overprice those now. The raids are fun. But all the other raids, other than girgashy and the black/white dragon, I think those need better drops. Girgashy raids though, when it comes to that, Most of the people i notice that do those, are really strict Unhelpful unfriendly elitists. They can be very troll like and rude, But the community and people in the game, should hang in there and try to help eachother out for there experiences to be better.Elves and giants. Now about both sides.  The players can have alot of racism between the two. Elves and Giants i admit they barely. Even Get anything good. Humans Practically get everything. Elves need Better archer skills. Also A melee talent and better magic for themselfs. Giants. I think should be able to duel wield all one handed melee weapons, not just swords and blunts. Idk why but you cant duel wield blunts as human same with axes, But with swords you can. Im not sure if you can with giants though. But im kinda doubting it. Humans also get alot of towns to themselfs, where as elves and giants just get one. Uladh could use some real good field bosses to though. Tory ravine, hasn't been unlocked yet. I kind of like how they changed the dungeons. The rewards and stuff to. The event's are mostly Afk events so you can make alot of gold selling the stuff from those. Some of the event's can be fun to. The Premium Service and VIP Service are outdated. Only good for housing.The thing is though, The game  currently Makes me feel like You have to pay to do something good, and worth doing. It's currently Building up more and more. But not into something worth doing. Like sure its free to play, but it  does feel like it's turning into a really bad free to pay, to regret it afterwards aswell. So that's it. That's my review It's really upto you and your preferances for your likings to the game.If anyone needs help with the game just note me ingame. Sorry for my bad grammar though.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I'm sure for those that it works for, this game is a lot of fun. It looks really neat and I love the idea of being able to choose between being an adventurer, or just chilling and going for a more relaxed alternative like becoming a chef or a tailor, or a farmer and fisherman/woman. Unfortunately, the game keeps freezing for me repeatedly no matter what. After creating my character, it froze while loading me into the world to begin. I couldn't find any way to close out of the game, as nothing on my keyboard worked. So I was forced to shut down my computer just so I could close the game. Still hoping it would work, I tried loading it up a second time and I thought it was fine. I could move around, perform actions (Like laughing, greeting, dancing, disapproving ect) but I heard no background music. So I found the Menu button and tried to hit Options, hoping I could turn the music on and maybe figure out what I ought to be doing. Unfortunately, when I hit Options, my game froze once more and I could find no means of escaping. F1-12 buttons didn't work, neither did the Fn keys, and not even the ever reliable Escape key let me get out of the game. I am not sure if its because this particular mmorpg is popular, and therefore it has terrible and severe lag....or my laptop just can't handle it. Which I would sincerely doubt, as I have Windows 10 on my laptop, and it's a Lenovo ideapad Y700.It's really a shame I couldn't get the game to work, it looked like it would be a lot of fun and I was really looking forward to the idea of creating my own homestead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												I just wanted to note before I go on that the hours on above are innacurate. I have actually played this game much, much more than four hours, I just linked the wrong account to my Steam, so I play it through the Nexon launcher.Mabinogi is a very fun game, but it's very hit and miss depending on the person. You either enjoy it or hate it, and it just depends on who you are. Because it's free to play, I would reccomend at least trying it out for a little bit and see if you get a feel for it. No risk involved!It doooes have some pay to win elements to it, but not so drastically that it's absolutely required. In the beggining of the game, it's not so bad. It's actually better now then it used to be, as they have made the game a lot easier, and give you a free mount to begin with. As you go on, there starts to become a little pressure to buy some things. It doesn't make quests easier or anything, you're not ridiculously weak without it, it simply makes the game more enjoyable. It makes for more character customization, the pets are amazing (probably the best investment in the game, I would say), and the gachapons are usually fun to play and very addicting. I have spent QUITE a bit of money on the game myself, and so have many many of the players, not so much because you have to, more because they manage to make it so appealing.As weird as it is to say, I actually don't think the battle mechanics or general game play are the best part of the game. Battle can be fun, but it can also get tedious and annoying. It gets pretty repetative, but as you get farther there are more and more fun skills. However, battle doesn't even have to be all that prevalent. There are a lot of different classes to play, some for different kinds of combat, others for different life styles entirely. Don't feel like fighting? Be a chef, be a cleric, be a bard! Most of them are very interesting and fun to try out, but most people tend to find their niche and stick with it.The world is huge, and there's a lot of different places to see and things to do. Despite the sort of lack luster graphics, some of the scenery can be very beautiful! There's a lot of different activities, mobs, and dungeons around and most of them are very fun!The game is okay to play solo at first, but the further you get into it, the more it becomes a multiplayer kinda game. I've actually kind of fallen out of the game a bit because I don't have a lot of friends to play the game with. My advice is to just be social. The game is WAY MORE FUN with friends!There's a lot of short quest lines in the game with little mini stories to them, and also a lot of lone quests to play. But I would say the best quests are the story line quests. Not because they have better objectives and things to do, as far as I've noticed it's a lot of playing messanger. But! I think the stories are very fun to follow. They're pretty interesting, and it's fun to learn the lore! As far as the npcs go, it's a large spectrum between awesome and annoying as hell. Most characters aren't so bad, but everybody has some they hate.All in all I would reccomend giving it a shot. If you don't like it, it's just a little time spent, not really any other risks. If you do end up liking it, though, there's a lot of game to have fun with, and you can make some pretty good friends!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												This game is easily one of my favorites. I've not played it as long as some people, but overall I've got around (Edit) 550 hours (Including Steam & Non-Steam Hours). The game has many stories in it, even some from Shakespeare, some of my personal favorites. There's plenty of events to keep you occupied. Even if you get bored of the game, which for me, was after around 150 hours, you'll be wanting to come back to it eventually and I played it even longer after coming back to it. Story : 10/10 - Takes far longer to beat than plenty of games I've ever played and has multiple stories. Graphics : 6.5/10 - The game runs on an older engine, so graphics aren't the best, but the artwork is beautiful.  Combat : 8.5/10 - While it certainly isn't as fun as the combat in TERA (Another amazing mmorpg), the combat is better than that of many mmo's I've played. Community : 7.5/10 - The game is rather old so there's not as many players as there could be on it. Overall, the community's fun, helpful, and rather friendly. As far as being helpful goes, many experienced players are willing to help new players get a grasp on the game's key features, especially combat.  Gameplay : 9/10 - There's enough to keep you busy for a while, so there's not much to hate about it.Overall, this game was great and I plan to keep coming back to it. The game definitely deserves more attention & players than it gets. If I was to go over everything in this game, this review would be several paragraphs longer so try the game out for yourself :PEdit: The only thing I disliked about this game was it being owned by Nexon. I've typically not enjoyed games they own but this one is different and doesn't have a pay-to-win feel like other games I've played.
